Award.AwardTitle: REU Site: Nuclear Science at Texas A&M University
Award.AbstractNarration:
This award provides continued support for the REU site at the Cyclotron Institute at Texas A&M University (TAMU). The new award includes a collaboration with Lawrence Livermore National Laboratory (LLNL) and a significantly refined outreach activity, Street Physics.

The need for increased efforts in recruiting the next generation of young people into nuclear science was recently emphasized in a report by the Nuclear Science Advisory Committee. Involvement in research at the undergraduate level is believed to be an important component in increasing the numbers and preparation of students entering graduate programs. The students supported through this award will be in residence for 10 weeks in conjunction with the summer session at TAMU, for which they will receive a $5000 fellowship, housing, travel and most importantly the opportunity to work closely with internationally renowned scientists at a first-rate university-based nuclear facility. The research projects are at the leading edge Nuclear Science, including sub-fields such as nuclear astrophysics, weak interactions, nuclear dynamics and thermodynamics, nuclear structure, RHIC, atomic ionizations, and radiation effects. There are proposed projects both in theoretical and experimental Nuclear Science. Some students will work at the Cyclotron Institute, which is a DOE Nuclear Physics Center of Excellence. The facilities include a K500 superconducting cyclotron, a K150 cyclotron and associated state-of the art detector systems. The Cyclotron Institute and the department of physics are also home base for involvement in experiments at other facilities, such as RHIC, ANL, and TRIUMF. The faculty at TAMU are leading scientists in the field and have a history of working with undergraduates in their research programs.

ProgramReference.Text: REU SITE-Res Exp for Ugrd Site

POR.DRECONTENT:
Each summer the Cyclotron Institute at Texas A&M University has been the host for a 10-week Research Experience for Undergraduates (REU) program. The primary goal of the program is to provide undergraduate students the opportunity to participate in cutting edge research in both theoretical and experimental nuclear science under the supervision of leading scientists in the field. Students participate in research groups and conduct collaborative research with post-doctoral scientists, graduate students and other undergraduate students in addition to their primary adviser. For this program, the primary target students are from demographics that are underrepresented in physics. We also target students whose home institutions lack the facilities and opportunities for this type of research.

During this program, each student gets a rare research experience at an early stage of their career. They are also able to build useful cross-disciplinary skills as each student is expected to present the results of their research in two different forms at the end of each summer. Each student participates in a campus wide poster session with students from similar programs in different disciplines. They must also provide a 15-minute, conference style, oral presentation to employees and students of the Cyclotron Institute. Each research group advises and guides the students in preparation for these presentations as most students have little experience presenting scientific findings in this form. In addition to the local presentations, students are both encouraged to attend and financially assisted in getting to the Division of Nuclear Physics Fall Meeting each October to present their posters as part of the Conference Experience for Undergraduates program. Roughly half of the REU students during this time frame have had the benefit of attending this conference. At this conference students present their research to one of the largest gathering of nuclear science researchers in the country. By doing so, they gain exposure in the field as well attend a graduate school fair hosted by the most highly decorated schools in the country that offer degrees in nuclear science.

In terms of a broad impact, the primary goal and outcome of this REU program is to provide students with professional development, not only in nuclear science, but research in general. The secondary goal of the program is to help the students determine potential career paths by exposing them to this frontier of research. To aid this effort, each summer we bring in alumni of our graduate school for a Career Day to talk to the students about their career paths and the truly varied number of options that students in this field have in front of them. This Career Day, and the REU program in general works toward our tertiary goal of recruiting new, young scientists into the field of nuclear science for long term careers. This provides a number of broad, long lasting benefits to society.
